awd_titl_txt: Molecular Information and Crystal Control in Solid State Photochemistry. Radical Pair Dynamics, Synthetic Applications and Triplet Quantum Chains
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most interesting and promising frontiers in the chemical sciences involves the use of crystalline solids exposed to light for the purpose of carrying out special chemical transformations.  Reactions in crystals differ from processes in liquids and in gases because molecules in the crystalline state are held rigidly and orderly, such that they all have the same fate when a reaction occurs. With support from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Miguel A. Garcia-Garibay of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at The University of California, Los Angeles, uses crystals to explore two types of unusual but promising chemical reactions.  One reaction examines the effect of magnetic fields.  Magnetic fields play a role in the navigation systems of migrating birds and have the potential to control some types of chemical systems.  The second reaction, known as a quantum chain reaction, is process where a single light particle, or photon, leads to many chemical events (an amplification process). Quantum chain reactions in crystals are enabled by strong interactions between neighboring molecules. This interaction transforms photons into moveable "excitons",  facilitated by chemical reactions that retain and unleash large amounts of energy.  A third objective of this grant is to demonstrate the advantages of reactions in crystals for the conversion of simple chemicals into high value substances. This multifaceted project provides an excellent multi-disciplinary training ground for students in quantum information systems (QIS).  It helps develop the intellectual and human infrastructure needed to support our country's academic and industrial enterprises related to quantum computing, quantum biology, and sensing. The connection between biological systems and molecules in crystals provides Professor Garcia-Garibay with an opportunity to develop a freshman-level course on the role of light in the origins of life. This course develops multimedia teaching and demonstration aids that are shared with the general public.

Over the last few years the Garcia-Garibay group has established the structural requirements needed to engineer reactions in crystalline solids.  This project addresses three aspects of chemical dynamics that have not been accessible by studying reactions in liquid solutions or in the gas phase.  First, by taking advantage of crystalline ketones which have radical stabilizing substituents at the two alpha-carbons, the researchers are able to generate triplet radical pairs under conditions not available previously.  With strongly interacting spins, these radical pairs have a relatively large Singlet-Triplet energy gap.  When combined with the use of nanocrystalline suspensions as a medium to carry out laser flash photolysis (pump-probe) experiments, this project provides a unique opportunity to measure the dynamics of intersystem crossing in the solid state.  Structural modifications of the starting ketone measured by single crystal X-ray diffraction and solid state nuclear magnetic resonance provide opportunities to analyze the kinetics of the triplet excited states and sequential radical pair intermediates. The interplay of spin dynamics and chemical dynamics is probed by measuring the kinetics of intersystem crossing as a function of external magnetic fields and magnetic isotope effects.  Other aspects of solid state photochemical reactivity that are encompassed by this project include the total synthesis of the natural product Chimonanthin using solid state photodecarbonylation as the key step.  The triplet exciton-enabled quantum chain reaction of crystalline Dewar benzenes is also explored. This chain process is expected to give a large number of product molecules per photon absorbed. Altogether, the research activities in this project improve the fundamental understanding of reaction mechanisms and chemical reactivity in rigid materials and provide students with an opportunity to receive a highly interdisciplinary training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first objective of this project was to investigate the use of crystalline solids as an effective way to control the outcome of otherwise chaotic photochemical reactions.  Photochemical reactions are those that occur when electrons in stable molecular orbitals are promoted by the absorption of light into high energy orbitals, which leads to the formation of excited states that are prone to the cleavage chemical bonds and the formation of highly unstable radical fragments.  While such radicals generated in biological tissues, plastics, or other materials tend to be highly chaotic and destructive, this project has shown that crystalline solid can make them useful. Indeed, while many photochemical reactions in the gas phase, in liquids, and in soft materials tend to very chaotic because their excited states find many ways to react, reactions in crystals take place under high structural control.  This work helped confirm that reactions in crystals can be ?engineered? by taking advantage of knowledge on reaction mechanisms available from studies carried out in liquid media. The ideal crystalline substrates consist of molecules that are able break two or more chemical bonds in a rapid and consecutive manner upon exposure to Ultraviolet light.  While those reactions tend to be the most challenging in solution, within the rigid and highly ordered environment of a crystalline solid, they take place under remarkable levels of control, in ways that a single product is generally observed.  As molecules in rigid crystals are unable to move, reactants, highly energetic intermediates, and products must be structurally similar, and many such reactions occur from a pure crystalline reactant to a nearly pure crystalline product.  It has been shown that reactions in crystals are useful in the synthesis of complex natural products that are difficult to obtain by conventional means, as illustrated by the synthesis of compounds with two bulky carbon atoms adjacent to each other, including the first total synthesis of the complex alkaloid psychotriadine.  This compound is part of a family of natural products with high biological activity and it will now be available for biological studies.  Furthermore, with a key step where light is the only reagent, reactions in crystals are a promising alternative for the green chemical synthesis of structurally challenging compounds.

The second objective of this work addressed the direct detection of radicals generated by light excitation in the crystalline state to improve and expand our understanding of chemical dynamics into unchartered territories of chemical kinetics.  Studies were carried out with submicron crystals (200-500 nm) suspended in water using fast laser pulses to generate the excited states and radical intermediates. It was confirmed that radical pairs generated in the solid state can be observed with spectroscopic methods established in solution, and that the two radicals remain with reacting distances for surprisingly long times.  This discovery is particularly important as it implies that two radicals are not able to make a chemical bond even though they are forced to remain at a very close distance.  The reason why they are not able to make a chemical bond is because quantum mechanics requires the two electrons to have opposite spins. This implies that shorter distance within crystals causes the two electrons to remain entangled for extremely long times, making them potential candidates for a new ?qubit? platform in the emerging field of quantum information science.  In principle, a new class of qubits could be generated in suitable crystals with a laser pulse, use them for logical operations using magnets and microwaves for as long as they remain entangled, and have them recycle once they can make a bond back to the starting material.   

The third part of this project entailed the development of a relatively unusual class of photochemical reactions where a single photon can lead to the formation of multiple products, in a process known as a quantum chain.   While theory predicts that suitable reactions carried out in the crystalline state have the potential of generating up to 106 product molecules per photon absorbed, the first attempt led to values between 100 to 300 reaction per photon. This confirmed the potential of reactions in crystals as a promising strategy for signal amplification, which may lead to powerful tools for dosimetric and sensing applications.

The ffinal and most critical accomplishment of this project involved the development of human resources by enabling the engagement of a diverse group of students as well as postdoctoral fellows who became experts in organic synthesis, organic photochemistry, transient spectroscopy, single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction measurements, solid state NMR, thermal analysis, and computational methods.  Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows participated in various aspects of the projects sponsored by this grant and contributed with outreach activities with local community colleges and nearby undergraduate institutions.
